CONJUGATES: grace (singular noun) | graces (plural noun) | grace (verb, base form) | graces (3rd person singular present) | graced (past simple, past participle) | gracing (present participle)
ETYMOLOGY: From Old French grace, from Latin gratia 'pleasing quality, favour, thanks'.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A noun is a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: She danced with such grace that everyone admired her.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 她舞姿如此优美，令每个人都赞叹不已。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A noun is a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: The free and unmerited favour of God, as manifested in the salvation of sinners and the bestowing of blessings.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: They believed they were saved by God's grace.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他们相信是靠上帝的恩典才得救的。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A noun is a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
